commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons [--all|--app APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mlists your add-ons and attachments[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -A, --all            [2mshow add-ons and attachments for all accessible apps[22m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --json               [2mreturn add-ons in json format[22m

The default filter applied depends on whether you are in a Heroku app
directory. If so, the --app flag is implied. If not, the default of --all
is implied. Explicitly providing either flag overrides the default
behavior.

Examples:

    $ heroku addons --all
    $ heroku addons --app acme-inc-www

commands.description: attach add-on resource to a new app
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:attach ADDON_NAME [34m[flags][39m

[1mattach add-on resource to a new app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP            [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE      [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --as AS                  [2mname for add-on attachment[22m
 --confirm CONFIRM        [2moverwrite existing add-on attachment with same name[22m
 --credential CREDENTIAL  [2mcredential name for scoped access to Heroku Postgres[22m
helpLine: [2mattach add-on resource to a new app[22m

commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:create SERVICE:PLAN [34m[flags][39m

[1mcreate an add-on resource[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --as AS              [2mname for the initial add-on attachment[22m
 --confirm CONFIRM    [2moverwrite existing config vars or existing add-on attachments[22m
 --name NAME          [2mname for the add-on resource[22m
 --wait               [2mwatch add-on creation status and exit when complete[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:add SERVICE:PLAN [34m[flags][39m

[1mcreate an add-on resource[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --as AS              [2mname for the initial add-on attachment[22m
 --confirm CONFIRM    [2moverwrite existing config vars or existing add-on attachments[22m
 --name NAME          [2mname for the add-on resource[22m
 --wait               [2mwatch add-on creation status and exit when complete[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:destroy [ADDON]... [flags] [34m[flags][39m

[1mdestroy add-on resources[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP          [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -f, --force            [2mallow destruction even if connected to other apps[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE    [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:destroy [ADDON]... [flags] [34m[flags][39m

[1mdestroy add-on resources[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP          [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -f, --force            [2mallow destruction even if connected to other apps[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE    [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

commands.description: open an add-on's Dev Center documentation in your browser
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:docs ADDON [34m[flags][39m

[1mopen an add-on's Dev Center documentation in your browser[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --show-url           [2mshow URL, do not open browser[22m
helpLine: [2mopen an add-on's Dev Center documentation in your browser[22m

commands.description: list all available plans for an add-on services
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:plans SERVICE [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist all available plans for an add-on services[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 --json  [2moutput in json format[22m
helpLine: [2mlist all available plans for an add-on services[22m

commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:rename ADDON NEW_NAME [34m[flags][39m

[1mRename an add-on.[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:services [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist all available add-on services[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 --json  [2moutput in json format[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:upgrade ADDON [PLAN] [34m[flags][39m

[1mchange add-on plan[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

See available plans with `heroku addons:plans SERVICE`.

Note that `heroku addons:upgrade` and `heroku addons:downgrade` are the same.
Either one can be used to change an add-on plan up or down.

[https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons)

Examples:

  Upgrade an add-on by service name:

    $ heroku addons:upgrade heroku-redis:premium-2

  Upgrade a specific add-on:

    $ heroku addons:upgrade swimming-briskly-123 heroku-redis:premium-2

[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:downgrade ADDON [PLAN] [34m[flags][39m

[1mchange add-on plan[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

See available plans with `heroku addons:plans SERVICE`.

Note that `heroku addons:upgrade` and `heroku addons:downgrade` are the same.
Either one can be used to change an add-on plan up or down.

[https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons)

Examples:

  Upgrade an add-on by service name:

    $ heroku addons:upgrade heroku-redis:premium-2

  Upgrade a specific add-on:

    $ heroku addons:upgrade swimming-briskly-123 heroku-redis:premium-2

commands.description: Show provisioning status of the add-ons on the app
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku addons:wait ADDON [34m[flags][39m

[1mShow provisioning status of the add-ons on the app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP                  [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE            [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --wait-interval WAIT-INTERVAL  [2mhow frequently to poll in seconds[22m
helpLine: [2mShow provisioning status of the add-ons on the app[22m

topics.name: addons
topics.description: tools and services for developing, extending, and operating your app
topics.overview:
Overview of Add-ons:

  Add-ons are created with the `addons:create` command, providing a reference
  to an add-on service (such as `heroku-postgresql`) or a service and plan
  (such as `heroku-postgresql:hobby-dev`).

  At creation, each add-on is given a globally unique name. In addition, each
  add-on has at least one attachment alias to each application which uses the
  add-on. In all cases, the owning application will be attached to the add-on.
  An attachment alias is unique to its application, and is used as a prefix to
  any environment variables it exports to the application.

  In this example, a `heroku-postgresql` add-on is created and its given name
  is `postgresql-deep-6913` with a default attachment alias of `DATABASE`:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app
    Creating postgresql-deep-6913... done, (free)
    Adding postgresql-deep-6913 to my-app... done
    Setting DATABASE_URL and restarting my-app... done, v5
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  The add-on name and, in some cases, the attachment alias can be specified by
  the user. For instance, we can add a second database to the app, specifying
  both these identifiers:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app --name main-db --as PRIMARY_DB
    Creating main-db... done, (free)
    Adding main-db to my-app... done
    Setting PRIMARY_DB_URL and restarting my-app... done, v6
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    └─ as PRIMARY_DB

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  Attachment aliases can also be specified when making attachments:

    $ heroku addons:attach main-db --app my-app --as ANOTHER_NAME
    Attaching main-db as ANOTHER_NAME to my-app... done
    Setting ANOTHER_NAME vars and restarting my-app... done, v7

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    ├─ as PRIMARY_DB
    └─ as ANOTHER_NAME

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  For more information, read [https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/add-ons](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/add-ons).
